questions.question: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting 1,3-beta-glucan synthase?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Caspofungin Explanation: Caspofungin, an echinocandin antifungal, inhibits 1,3-beta-glucan synthase, disrupting fungal cell wall synthesis and causing cell lysis and death. Cell wall inhibiting antifungals: Act by inhibiting the enzyme 1,3-beta-glucan synthase, essential for fungal cell wall formation. Caspofungin Micafungin Anidulafungin Cell membrane inhibiting antifungals: Drugs Mechanism of action Natamycin (Option A) Binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, disrupting membrane integrity. Terbinafine (Option D) It inhibits squalene epoxidase, reduces ergosterol synthesis, and affects cell membrane integrity. Amphotericin B Binds to ergosterol, forming pores in the fungal cell membrane, leading to cell death. Fluconazole, Itraconazole, Ketoconazole (Option B) Inhibits ergosterol synthesis, affecting cell membrane function. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 841

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true regarding Amphotericin B?

options.A: Acts by binding to ergosterol in fungal cell membranes.
options.B: Liposomal AMB is associated with lower nephrotoxicity than conventional AMB.
options.C: AMB is absorbed orally, making it suitable for treatment with systemic mycoses.
options.D: Drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) AMB is absorbed orally, making it suitable for treatment with systemic mycoses. therapeutic levels in the bloodstream and treat systemic fungal infections. Aspect Amphotericin B Mechanism of Action Binds to ergosterol in fungal cell membranes (Option A) , forming pores that disrupt membrane integrity, leading to leakage of cellular contents and fungal cell death. Preparation Conventional Amphotericin B (c-AMB) Amphotericin B lipid complex (ABLC) Liposomal Amphotericin B (L-AMB) Use Cryptococcal meningitis (Option D) , mucormycosis, coccidioidal meningitis. Adverse Effects Nephrotoxicity: Most notable with conventional Amphotericin B (c-AMB); less with liposomal formulations (Option B) . Fever, chills, and hypotension can be managed with pre-treatment (NSAIDs, antihistamines). Anemia (requires erythropoietin treatment). Renal tubular acidosis leads to electrolyte imbalances (hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia). Arachnoiditis, when used intrathecally Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 839

questions.question: Which drug belongs to the triazole group of antifungals known for its broad spectrum against yeast and moulds, including mucormycosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Posaconazole Explanation: Posaconazole is the triazole antifungal known for its broad spectrum against yeast and moulds, including mucormycosis. Imidazoles Triazoles Miconazole (Option A ruled out) Clotrimazole (Option C ruled out) Ketoconazole (Option D ruled out) Posaconazole (Option B) Fluconazole Itraconazole Voriconazole Aspect Posaconazole Mechanism of Action Inhibits fungal sterol 14 α -demethylase, disrupting ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes. Spectrum of Activity Broad spectrum against various fungi, including Aspergillus spp., Candida spp., and Mucorales (effective against mucormycosis). Adverse Effects Common: Nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, headache, dizziness. Rare: Anaemia, neutropenia, cardiac arrhythmias, visual disturbances. Route of Administration Absorption of oral suspension is enhanced by low pH and fatty foods. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 847

questions.question: All of the following azoles are primarily excreted through bile except?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Fluconazole Explanation: Fluconazole is the only azole among the options that is primarily excreted via the kidneys (urine) . The rest of the azoles - Ketoconazole, Itraconazole, and Posaconazole - undergo hepatic metabolism and are primarily excreted via bile . Therefore, Fluconazole stands out for its renal clearance and dose adjustments are required in renal impairment . Excretion patterns of azoles: Azole Route of Excretion Dose Adjustment in Renal Failure Fluconazole Renal (urine) Yes Ketoconazole Hepatic (bile) No Itraconazole Hepatic (bile) No Posaconazole Hepatic (bile, feces) No Ketoconazole (Option A): Incorrect because it is extensively metabolized in the liver and eliminated via the biliary route . Itraconazole (Option B): Incorrect because it is lipophilic , has hepatic metabolism , and is excreted mainly in bile . Posaconazole (Option C): Incorrect as it is also primarily excreted via feces , indicating biliary excretion . Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 844

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman visits the dermatology clinic with a persistent and intensely itchy rash on her arms, legs, and trunk. She mentions that over-the-counter antihistamines have provided minimal relief. Which azole drug with antipruritic effects would be most suitable for managing her condition?
questions.explanation: well-suited for managing dermatological conditions associated with itching. Fluconazole, Itraconazole, Voriconazole, and Posaconazole are other azole drugs that lack significant anti-pruritic properties. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 845-847

Seborrheic Dermatitis Ketoconazole (topical and oral) Inhibits fungal cytochrome P450-dependent enzyme. Mucormycosis Amphotericin B Disrupts fungal cell membrane integrity. questions.question: A kidney transplant patient receiving cyclosporine develops a new fungal infection and is prescribed ketoconazole for treatment. What is the potential consequence of adding ketoconazole to the patient's regimen?

options.B: Elevated risk of toxicity with cyclosporine
options.C: No significant interaction between ketoconazole and cyclosporine

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Elevated risk of toxicity with cyclosporine . Explanation: Ketoconazole is a strong CYP3A4 inhibitor . Cyclosporine is metabolized by CYP3A4. When ketoconazole is co-administered, it inhibits cyclosporine metabolism , leading to elevated blood levels . This significantly increases the risk of cyclosporine-induced toxicity , especially nephrotoxicity and neurotoxicity . Drug Interactions: Drug Mechanism Impact on Cyclosporine Cyclosporine Immunosuppressant; CYP3A4 substrate Narrow therapeutic index; toxic if elevated Ketoconazole CYP3A4 inhibitor Reduces metabolism → ↑ cyclosporine levels Adverse Effects of Ketoconazole: System Adverse Effects Hepatic Hepatotoxicity (boxed warning); can be severe or fatal Endocrine Inhibits steroidogenesis → ↓ cortisol/testosterone → gynecomastia, impotence GI Nausea, vomiting, abdominal discomfort Skin Pruritus, rash QT Prolongation Risk of torsades de pointes when combined with other QT-prolonging drugs Decreased effectiveness of cyclosporine (Option A): Incorrect. Ketoconazole increases , not decreases, cyclosporine levels by inhibiting its metabolism. No significant interaction between ketoconazole and cyclosporine (Option C): Incorrect. The interaction is clinically significant ; it mandates dose adjustment and close monitoring . Enhanced elimination of cyclosporine (Option D): Incorrect. Ketoconazole slows elimination by inhibiting CYP3A4, leading to drug accumulation. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 844

Preferred for mucormycosis; Can cause hepatotoxicity 4.Posaconazole d. Preferred for prophylaxis in immunocompromised patients; Can cause gastrointestinal upset
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Explanation: Fluconazole Itraconazole Voriconazole Posaconazole Mechanism of Action Inhibits fungal cytochrome P450-dependent enzyme lanosterol 14 α -demethylase, leading to inhibition of ergosterol synthesis. questions.question: A 23-year-old man comes to the dermatology OPD. After examination, a diagnosis of onychomycosis was made, and he was started on oral terbinafine. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

options.D: Formation of pore in ergosterol membrane

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Inhibition of squalene epoxidase Explanation: Aspects Terbinafine Mechanism of action Competitive inhibition of squalene epoxidase (Option C) ↓ Accumulation of squalene within fungal cells ↓ Inhibition of ergosterol synthesis ↓ Disruption of fungal cell membrane integrity ↓ Fungicidal action Features It has a high affinity for sebum and thus accumulates in sebum, stratum corneum and nails. Uses Topical: Used for treating tinea infections (ringworm) and pityriasis versicolor (fungal skin infection). Oral: DOC for onychomycosis (fungal infection of the nails), tinea capitis (scalp ringworm), and extensive fungal lesions. It is also used in oromucosal candidiasis as an alternative to fluconazole. Side effects Taste disturbance and rash; topical application causes dryness, itching and irritation. Inhibition of thymidylate synthase (Option A) Flucytosine (5-FC) converts into 5-fluorodeoxyuridylic acid within the fungal cell and acts as an inhibitor of thymidylate synthase. It is a narrow-spectrum fungistatic agent active towards Cryptococcus neoformans and chromoblastomyces. questions.question: An 18-year-old high school student presents to the dermatology outpatient clinic with symptoms of tinea pedis and tinea capitis. The dermatologist opts for an antifungal agent that inhibits microtubules within fungal cells, thereby preventing mitosis. Which drug was most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Griseofulvin Explanation: Aspects Griseofulvin MOA Inhibition of microtubules within the fungal cells, thus inhibiting mitosis. It results in the formation of multi-nucleated and stunted fungal hyphae. Features Keratinophilic thus gets deposited in high concentration in Stratum corneum, hair and nails Plasma half-life is 24 hours Uses DOC in Superficial fungal infections such as Tinea. (T. capitis- most effective; T.curis , T.unguium, T.corporis- less effective; T. versicolor – it is not effective) Side effects Headache Neuritis Hepatitis Photosensitivity Disulfiram like reaction Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page 841, 842, 848

questions.question: A 65-year-old diabetic patient is admitted to the ICU with meningitis. He reported contact with pigeon droppings two weeks prior. India ink staining of his CSF sample confirmed Cryptococcus neoformans infection. What is the most appropriate drug combination for treating this fungal infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Amphotericin B + Flucytosine Explanation: The treatment of choice for cryptococcal meningitis combines IV Amphotericin B and IV Flucytosine. Mechanism of action Uses Side effects Amphotericin B (Polyene antibiotic molecule) Forms micropores in the ergosterol membrane. Cryptococcus neoformans Leishmania Nephrotoxicity Allergic reaction Arachnoiditis Anemia Flucytosine (pyrimidine antimetabolite) Inhibitor of thymidylate synthase Cryptococcus neoformans Chromoblastomyces. Dose-dependent marrow suppression Enteritis. Caspofungin + Flucytosine (Option A) is used in the treatment of systemic candidiasis in an immunocompromised patient Voriconazole + Caspofungin (Option C) is used to treat invasive aspergillosis. Amphotericin B + Posaconazole (Option D) is used in the treatment of mucormycosis Reference: 1. K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 839-844, 846-847 2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5447657/
